Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Expectation2: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation2: A recently updated standard will apply to the upcoming release, and evidence of conformity is required
Story:
I stood at the edge of the skate park, clipboard in hand, my mind still tangled in the technical checklist I’d been reviewing all morning. My stepbrother, Jamie, was tightening his helmet, grinning at me as he eyed the steep, uneven ramp. “Watch this, I’ve been practicing all week,” he called out, already rolling his board into position. As his step-sibling, I was supposed to look out for him, make sure he didn’t get hurt. But as an engineer, my thoughts kept drifting to the new safety standard at work—how every detail had to be documented, every risk accounted for, or the project could be delayed. 

Jamie’s ramp was nowhere near compliant with any standard I knew. The cracks, the loose boards, the uneven slope—my professional instincts screamed at me to intervene, to stop him, to insist on a safer setup. But he looked so excited, so sure of himself, and I knew how much this meant to him. My heart pounded as I weighed my responsibility to him as family against my ingrained duty to safety and rules. I opened my mouth, torn between warning him and letting him have his moment.
